body:
### Neovim version (nvim -v)

0.6.0 Release

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no, vim 8.2.4096 works regardless of terminal emulator (version) and/or TERM value

### Operating system/version

OpenBSD 7.0-current

### Terminal name/version

XTerm/OpenBSD(369)

### $TERM environment variable

xterm

### Installation

system package manager

### How to reproduce the issue

1. set `XTERM` to begin with `xterm`
2. set `XTERM_VERSION` to be non-empty
3. use defaults, no configuration
4. split windows vertically
5. scroll down one window such that at least one new line appears
6. observe the other window visually being scrolled and padded with blank lines accordingly
7. refresh screen (`^L`) to restore visual appearance

Setup/startup:
```
$ env -i TERM=xterm TERM_VERSION='XTerm/OpenBSD(369)' \
    "$(which nvim)" --clean -u NONE -V10./xterm-version-set-nonempty.log -O /usr/share/dict/words /usr/share/dict/words
```

Scrolling:
```
L
j
```

Observe visual artifacts, refresh screen, exit:
```
^L
:qa!
```

Repeating with xterm's version unset does not exibit the bahaviour:
```
$ env -i TERM=xterm \
    "$(which nvim)" --clean -u NONE -V10./xterm-version-unset.log -O /usr/share/dict/words /usr/share/dict/words
```

Difference between logs:
```
$ diff -u ./xterm-version-set-nonempty.log ./xterm-version-unset.log
--- ./xterm-version-set-nonempty.log
+++ ./xterm-version-unset.log
@@ -398,12 +398,9 @@
   set_background            setb       = <Esc>[4%?%p1%{1}%=%t4%e%p1%{3}%=%t6%e%p1%{4}%=%t1%e%p1%{6}%=%t3%e%p1%d%;m
   enter_italics_mode        sitm       = <Esc>[3m
   exit_italics_mode         ritm       = <Esc>[23m
-  set_left_margin_parm      smglp      = <Esc>[%i%p1%ds
-  set_right_margin_parm     smgrp      = <Esc>[%i;%p2%ds
   key_mouse                 kmous      = <Esc>[M
-  set_a_foreground          setaf      = <Esc>[%?%p1%{8}%<%t3%p1%d%e%p1%{16}%<%t9%p1%{8}%-%d%e38:5:%p1%d%;m
-  set_a_background          setab      = <Esc>[%?%p1%{8}%<%t4%p1%d%e%p1%{16}%<%t10%p1%{8}%-%d%e48:5:%p1%d%;m
-  set_lr_margin             smglr      = <Esc>[%i%p1%d;%p2%ds
+  set_a_foreground          setaf      = <Esc>[%?%p1%{8}%<%t3%p1%d%e%p1%{16}%<%t9%p1%{8}%-%d%e38;5;%p1%d%;m
+  set_a_background          setab      = <Esc>[%?%p1%{8}%<%t4%p1%d%e%p1%{16}%<%t10%p1%{8}%-%d%e48;5;%p1%d%;m
   set_tb_margin             smgtb      = <Esc>[%i%p1%d;%p2%dr
   memory_lock               meml       = <Esc>l
   memory_unlock             memu       = <Esc>m
@@ -484,8 +481,527 @@
   ext.get_bg                = <Esc>]11;?<C-G>
   ext.resize_screen         = <Esc>[8;%p1%d;%p2%dt
   ext.reset_scroll_region   = <Esc>[r
-  setrgbf                   = <Esc>[38:2:%p1%d:%p2%d:%p3%dm
-  setrgbb                   = <Esc>[48:2:%p1%d:%p2%d:%p3%dm
+  setrgbf                   = <Esc>[38;2;%p1%d;%p2%d;%p3%dm
+  setrgbb                   = <Esc>[48;2;%p1%d;%p2%d;%p3%dm
+  ext.set_cursor_color      = <Esc>]12;#%p1%06x<C-G>
+  ext.reset_cursor_color    = <Esc>]112<C-G>
+  ext.save_title            = <Esc>[22;0t
+  ext.restore_title         = <Esc>[23;0t
+  ext.enable_lr_margin      = <Esc>[?69h
+  ext.disable_lr_margin     = <Esc>[?69l
+  ext.enable_bpaste         = <Esc>[?2004h
+  ext.disable_bpaste        = <Esc>[?2004l
+  ext.enable_focus          = <Esc>[?1004h
+  ext.disable_focus         = <Esc>[?1004l
+  ext.enable_mouse          = <Esc>[?1002h<Esc>[?1006h
+  ext.disable_mouse         = <Esc>[?1002l<Esc>[?1006l
+}}}

+  smxx                      = <Esc>[9m
+  ext.get_bg                = <Esc>]11;?<C-G>
+  ext.resize_screen         = <Esc>[8;%p1%d;%p2%dt
+  ext.reset_scroll_region   = <Esc>[r
+  setrgbf                   = <Esc>[38;2;%p1%d;%p2%d;%p3%dm
+  setrgbb                   = <Esc>[48;2;%p1%d;%p2%d;%p3%dm
   ext.set_cursor_color      = <Esc>]12;#%p1%06x<C-G>
   ext.reset_cursor_color    = <Esc>]112<C-G>
   ext.save_title            = <Esc>[22;0t
```

### Expected behavior

neovim should scroll without visual artifacts regardless of terminal emulator (version).

### Actual behavior

Scrolling a single buffer with `TERM=xterm XTERM_VERSION=XTerm/OpenBSD(369)` effects all vertically adjacent buffers.

comment_data.body:
This sounds like https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/16238, which was fixed in 0.6.0, so you have those changes.

Your reproduction steps also make that clear, since when you don't have `XTERM_VERSION` set the `sgmlp` and `sgmrp` sequences aren't set.  What ncurses version do you have?

> This sounds like #16238, which was fixed in 0.6.0, so you have those changes.

Yup, the reproducer in this issue still triggers the same bug for me.

> Your reproduction steps also make that clear, since when you don't have `XTERM_VERSION` set the `sgmlp` and `sgmrp` sequences aren't set. What ncurses version do you have?

OpenBSD has ncurses 5.7, apparently at patchlevel 20081102, but OpenBSD's version in base also includes selected fixes from later version.

The cause of this is that `xterm` changes its behavior depending on the `decTerminalID` resource (OpenBSD's xterm defaults to vt100 for the terminal ID. See [xtermcfg.h](https://github.com/openbsd/xenocara/blob/65b0865690ef8e8e43ffd2cda89c442c9eb5f5b7/app/xterm/xtermcfg.h#L64)). I think we need to use `DECRQSS` instead of environment variables to determine if `smglr` is available.

As a workaround, use `xterm -ti vt420` or set the `decTerminalID` resource to `vt420` or 420.
If I had known about the capability for dumping patched termcap info from nvim, I would've saved some work in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/19040. Thanks for showing that @klemensn.

i will have to say that the current workaround is not great, as a common thing for xterm users is changing `decTerminalID` to `vt340` for sixel graphics support, a workaround i deployed on my system is to use a wrapper.

save this as `~/.local/bin/svim`
```sh
#!/bin/sh

unset XTERM_VERSION

# change to the correct nivm path on your system
exec /usr/bin/nvim "$@"
```

and then in your shell rc, be it bashrc or zshrc add an alias `alias nvim="svim"`

this should create the expected behaviour while allowing sixel graphics.

Thank you for the workaround!  I upgraded my system yesterday and this was driving me nuts, using

```
$ nvim --version
NVIM v0.9.4
Build type: Release
LuaJIT 2.1.1693350652

$ echo $XTERM_VERSION
XTerm(388)

$ tmux -V
tmux 3.3a
```
It was only broken when running nvim inside tmux, but `unset XTERM_VERSION` fixes it!

hah!, fun enough in the debian world, yes even unstable, we still are on nvim 0.7.2 because of how debian packaging standars require stuff to be packaged has some clashes with how rust conceives packages...

still i was not expecting this issue to still be a thing in nvim 0.9.4, oh well i guess with the coming of tmux 3.4 there will be more interest in sixel graphics and hopefully `DECRQSS` gets used to check for `smglr` rather and guess from env vars.

I think I'm encountering something similar in 0.10. 

Interestingly, I _didn't_ see this behavior in 0.9 but since upgrading to 0.10 it has been a constant source of annoyance. 

My steps to reproduce:

1. Open a long file (long enough it would flow off  the screen) in  nvim with `-u NORC`
2.  Create a new vertical split (^W V)
3. Move focus to the window on the right (^W L)
4.  Scroll down (L j j)
5. Notice that in addition to scrolling the right buffer, it also scrolls part of the buffer on the left, basically tearing the buffer in half.
6. Redraw fixes the artifacts (^L)

However, whether I get this behavior depends on the terminal I use. It happens in wezterm, but not in kitty, alacritty, or foot.  Also, if I change the TERM variable to `xterm`, or `xterm-256color` (isntead of `wezterm`) then it doesn't happen in wezterm either. Nor does it happen if I try in tmux inside of wezterm (TERM=tmux-256color). 

I have seen it happen in an older version of kitty (0.32) though, on Ubuntu 24.04 (My other testing was on archlinux). 

Here's a screencast of what I see:

[Kooha-2024-07-22-23-26-37.webm](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e539fcb6-9726-4b5c-801b-625717cc669d)

Interestingly, the playback of the [asciinema recording](https://asciinema.org/a/oXPDOEbsiGbzRr5j43m5uez3V) shows the whole buffer on the left being scrolled, not just part of it. I get a similar result if I play the asciinema recording in a different terminal, such as kitty.
This might be a wezterm bug for me though... see https://github.com/wez/wezterm/issues/5750

nope, just checked and i'm on neovim 0.9.5 in devuan testing:
NVIM v0.9.5
Build type: Release
LuaJIT 2.1.1719379426

and wouldn't you know, without the wrapper script from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/17142#issuecomment-1482085892 the scrolling of vertical adjacent buffers is still broken.

@tmccombs try the wrapper script and report back if it fixes your issue.
I do not have XTERM_VERSION set to begin with, the wrapper script wouldn't do anything.

I'm on nvim 0.10.2, with XTerm, and this problem still occurs if XTerm is set to run in VT340 mode (required for sixel support).

Thank you to @eylles for the dirty hack to make nvim work properly with that setup btw! ^^

> I'm on nvim 0.10.2, with XTerm, and this problem still occurs if XTerm is set to run in VT340 mode (required for sixel support).
> 
> Thank you to [@eylles](https://github.com/eylles) for the dirty hack to make nvim work properly with that setup btw! ^^

most of what i do may as well be dirty hacks, specially when it comes to xterm, tmux, neovim and scripts, i just need to make more of them public.

labels.description: issues specific to BSD descendants (please specify which in the issue)
labels.name: platform:bsd

labels.description: issue is not fixed but can be circumvented until then
labels.name: has:workaround

milestone.description: Low priority items. We plan to work on this but don't have a target date.
milestone.title: backlog

title: scrolling in true xterm ($XTERM_VERSION is defined) has visual glitches in all vertically adjacent buffers
